thread.title: Court stays controversial EPA water regulation
thread.title_full: Court stays controversial EPA water regulation | cleveland.com

author: Sabrina Eaton, Northeast Ohio Media Group Washington Correspondent
title: Court stays controversial EPA water regulation
text:
WASHINGTON, D.C. - A Cincinnati federal appeals court on Friday halted the Environmental Protection Agency from implementing a regulation that critics feared would give the federal government oversight over "almost every conceivable water body in the country" under the Clean Water Act.
Eighteen states including Ohio sued the federal government this summer, alleging the new rule would define "waters of the United States" to give the federal government jurisdiction over small tributaries "and even adjacent dry land and dry creek beds, with little limit on federal jurisdiction."
Ohio Attorney General Mike DeWine argued the rule violates the language and spirit of the decades-old Clean Water Act, which "recognizes the rights of states to serve as trustees of their natural resources." He expressed fear the federal government would use the overly broad definition of waters it oversees to improperly penalize landowners.
A panel of three judges on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit on Friday declared there's a "substantial possibility" that the states challenging the federal government in the case would succeed, and ordered the new rule to be stayed nationwide, pending the court's further review.
"A stay temporarily silences the whirlwind of confusion that springs from uncertainty about the requirements of the new Rule and whether they will survive legal testing," said the court's order, which was signed by Judges David McKeague and Richard Griffin. Judge Damon Keith issued a dissent that said he thought the court should determine whether it has jurisdiction before issuing a stay.
EPA released a statement that said it respects "the court's decision to allow for more deliberate consideration of the issues in the case" and looks forward to litigating its merits. It said its previous rule will remain in effect nationwide and it "will continue to apply the best science and technical data on a case-by-case basis to waters at issue. "
When announcing the rule's implementation earlier this year, top EPA and Army Corps officials said it would protect streams and wetlands from pollution and degradation by more clearly defining which waters are protected under the Clean Water Act.
"For the waters in the rivers and lakes in our communities that flow to our drinking water to be clean, the streams and wetlands that feed them need to be clean too," EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy said when the rule was finalized in June. She said the rule would "strengthen our economy and provide certainty to American businesses."
Jo-Ellen Darcy, an assistant secretary for the Army in charge of civil works, said the new rule responded "to the public's demand for greater clarity, consistency and predictability when making jurisdictional determinations."
DeWine issued a statement after the order was issued that said he's "glad that the Sixth Circuit Court has temporarily stopped the effect of this sweeping, illegal rule that claims federal jurisdiction over about every damp area of public or private land in the nation.
Congressman Bob Gibbs, a Holmes County Republican who vocally backed a House of Representatives bill to overturn the rule, said he was "pleased to see the Sixth Circuit Court put a stay on this disastrous and burdensome regulation," which he called "another example of the federal government overstepping its jurisdiction at the expense of the states." The House passed the bill but the Senate did not, and President Barack Obama has said he would veto the bill if it came to his desk.
"I call on the EPA to withdraw this costly regulation and start from scratch," said Gibbs, saying the EPA should collaborate with states to come up with a replacement.
